urn:contentItem:6GKV-9WM3-RY9B-V27D-00000-00Musk's SpaceX rocket succeeds in cargo test and begins return to Earth2025-08-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:58:42ZLexisNexisMusk's SpaceX rocket succeeds in cargo test and begins return to Earth


The tenth flight of Starship, the 122-meter rocket from Elon Musk's SpaceX, began successfully on Tuesday, 26, after two consecutive postponements this week - the test was initially scheduled for Sunday, 24, but a problem with systems at the rocket's ground base delayed the company's plans. On Monday 25th, the risk of lightning in a cloud near the site caused the test to be postponed.


On Tuesday, the spacecraft took off exactly at the time the window started at 8:30 pm (Brasília time). In 1 minute, the spacecraft reached 1,000 km/h. At 2min15sec, the spacecraft began separating from the Super Heavy launcher - 30 seconds later the process was complete. At 8.36pm, the Super Heavy returned to Earth, as scheduled by the company. This time, however, the equipment did not return to the company's base in Texas, but made a controlled landing in the waters of the Gulf of Mexico (renamed the Gulf of America by President Donald Trump).
After a 19-minute flight, at an altitude of 189 km, the company carried out a test by placing equipment simulating Starlink satellites, the company's internet system, into orbit. Eight pieces of equipment were put into space, one per minute on average. At 25 minutes 11 seconds into the mission, the load test was fully completed. This is the first time the Starship has carried out this type of simulation, which is a step forward for SpaceX after a series of failures in 2025.
After 45 minutes of flight, the Starship had already crossed the African continent and was at an altitude of 100 km, when it began the re-entry process - at this point, the rocket is traveling at 5 times the speed of sound. The plan is to make a controlled landing in the waters of the Indian Ocean, rather than recovering the rocket intact. SpaceX's plan is to test the Starship's thermal protection system, so the re-entry and landing are not expected to be smooth.
The Starship's tenth flight is the fourth test attempt this year, with all the previous ones ending in failure, which has put SpaceX's progress in check.
The last two tests resulted in the ship exploding in space. This is the tenth test of the rocket in total, from the company's facilities in Boca Chica, Texas.
According to SpaceX, after the previous incidents, "changes were made to the hardware and operations to increase reliability". For the tenth flight, the company plans to deploy payloads on the Starship for the first time, including eight Starlink simulators. They will be on the same suborbital trajectory as the Starship and should disintegrate upon entering the atmosphere. Other payloads had already been placed on the rocket, but as none of the attempts were completed, the test with the payloads could not be carried out either.
For this launch, the Super Heavy booster will not attempt to return to its point of origin, but will force land in the Gulf of America. The decision is aimed at avoiding damage to the launch base's infrastructure. Even so, the data collected during the flight should help shape the next versions of the rocket.
Another test should involve a maneuver in the rocket's return burn, which has already been carried out on the ninth flight. The move requires less propellant in reserve, allowing more fuel to be used during ascent to allow an additional payload mass into orbit.
History
In its first test, the rocket took off in April 2023, but exploded four minutes after launch, at an altitude of 39 kilometers, due to a propellant leak at the rear of the Super Heavy booster, which eventually cut the connection to the vehicle's main flight computer. According to Space X, this led to a loss of communications with most of the booster's engines and, ultimately, control of the vehicle.
At the time, the explosion caused damage to the Texan region, causing "dirt to rain down" on a town near the take-off, 10 km from the launch. The incident also caused a forest fire, prompting an environmental investigation in the USA.
In order to fly again, Space X had to comply with 63 requirements made by the US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) following the explosion. The changes included one related to the spacecraft separation process, in which the second stage, the Starship itself, turns on its engines during the same separation process, rather than afterwards, in order to obtain more power.
If everything went according to plan, the Starship's flight would last 90 minutes, reaching Earth's orbit and making an almost complete lap around the planet.
The fourth attempt was the first with 100% success in all stages of the flight, from the trajectory to the recovery of the booster and the landing of the spacecraft. Liftoff was achieved despite the fact that one of the launcher's 33 engines failed on ascent. Temperatures did not exceed fatal limits and the descent, aided by the atmosphere (which slows down the rocket), was stable. With this, the Starship is the largest rocket in history to make a full flight off the planet.
The fifth flight was the first to have the rocket's booster recovered at Starbase. In the test, carried out in October, the Heavy Booster was recaptured around 7 minutes after launch, by the launch tower itself, with two structures that simulate a kind of arm to hold the booster, called Mechazilla. The Starship landed in the Indian Ocean 1 hour and 5 minutes after leaving the launch base in Texas.
The seventh flight was the second to succeed in retrieving the booster from the launch tower, but the flight was not completed. About 8 minutes after take-off, the rocket lost contact with the control center and later exploded. SpaceX claimed that the problem was related to a leak in the spacecraft.
The eighth flight also had a problem that prevented the test from being successful. The flight was interrupted ahead of schedule after a failure in the attitude control system, responsible for maintaining the orientation of the spacecraft during its journey. According to SpaceX, the problem occurred around 8 minutes after launch, causing the rocket to lose control and fail to complete its mission of circling the Earth almost completely.
On the last attempt, at the end of May, just under 30 minutes into the flight, the rocket lost control of its flight altitude and started doing rotational "maneuvers" in space. In June, during an engine test for the tenth flight, the rocket also exploded.
Meet the Starship rocket
The Starship is the most powerful reusable rocket developed by Space X. Its aim is to take mankind to the Moon and then to Mars, a journey which is expected to cost between US$10 million and US$60 million. The company says that the rocket can be used to transport up to 150 tons of cargo on Earth, with journeys of up to an hour and a half to anywhere in the world.
"The Starship will be able to transport up to 100 people on long-duration interplanetary flights," Space X says on its website about the spacecraft. "The Starship will also help enable the delivery of satellites, the development of a lunar base and point-to-point transportation here on Earth."
The Starship is nicknamed the "rocket ship" because it is much larger than Space X's predecessor, the 70-meter Falcon 9. Its most recent sibling is 120 meters tall, 9 meters in diameter and weighs 1,300 tons.
The spacecraft carries the Super Heavy booster (69 meters high), which is responsible for taking the Starship into Earth orbit in around 170 seconds. The launcher has 33 Raptor engines, with a thrust of 72 meganewtons (twice that of the Falcon 9's Merlin engine). Like the main spacecraft, the launcher can be reused for new flights.
The Starship is 50 meters high, equipped with three Raptor engines and three more Raptor Vacuum engines, a model with a larger exhaust to maximize efficiency in space. The vehicle also has a liquid methane tank and another liquid oxygen tank for combustion.

urn:contentItem:6GKP-04W3-RXH7-6427-00000-00EU coordinates firefighting forces as wildfires sweep southern Europe2025-08-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:58:42ZLexisNexisEU coordinates firefighting forces as wildfires sweep southern EuropeAFP, AMNA, ANSA, ATA, BTA, dpa, EFE, Lusa, STA and TASR correspondents, as part of the enrBrussels (dpa/enr) -

EU countries are scrambling to fight wildfires through a coordinated civil protection force, as a record number of hectares have been left burned, generating unprecedented CO2 emissions.

EU countries are scrambling to fight wildfires through a coordinated civil protection force, as a record number of hectares have been left burned, generating unprecedented CO2 emissions.

Fires have been ravaging large swathes of southern Europe this month, while a prolonged and intense heatwave pushed temperatures above 40 degrees Celsius across much of the Mediterranean and the Balkans.

The prolonged periods of scorching heat dried out vegetation, which had grown rapidly in countries like Spain and Portugal after a wet spring, allowing the fires to burn more intensely and spread further.

Wildfires have so far ravaged more than 1 million hectares in the European Union in 2025, a record since statistics began in 2006, according to an AFP analysis based on estimates from the European Forest Fire Information System.

Between January and August 19, forest fires in 22 of the 27 EU countries emitted 35 megatons of carbon dioxide, an unprecedented amount at this point in the year according to EFFIS.

To battle the fires, countries can request assistance under the EU's Civil Protection Mechanism (UCPM), designed to improve cooperation between EU countries and ten additional states to respond to disasters.

By mid-August, the UCPM had been activated 16 times during this year's fire season, which typically runs roughly from June to September.

According to the European Commission, the number of activations for 2025 is already equal to the total for the 2024 fire season.

Southern Europe in flames

Most of southern Europe is still gripped by fires, and the UCPM is working at full speed to quench the flames. Here's how some countries have been fighting the fires.

Portugal

In Piódão in central Portugal, a fire started on August 13 and kept on burning for 11 days, consuming more than 64,000 hectares of land, according to the National Institute for Nature and Forests Conservation. Overall this year, more than 250,000 hectares have been destroyed by wildfires in Portugal.

On August 15, the government activated the UCPM. After the initial days of silence and lack of response by Interior Minister Maria Lúcia Amaral, the government and Prime Minister Luís Montenegro were accused of not taking the situation seriously.

After requesting assistance, Portugal received two Fire Boss airplanes and one Super Puma helicopter from France and two Canadair airplanes from Greece, along with 20 firefighters from Estonia and 20 from Malta. They will be in the country until August 29.

Spain

Spain is struggling with numerous fires in the west of the country. Over 400,000 hectares have been burned so far this year. Improved weather conditions have helped efforts to bring under control the 40 fires that were still active as of Monday.

Spain triggered the UCPM on August 13 - the first time that the country has ever asked other member states to help battle forest fires.

Spain received planes, helicopters and ground teams from France, Italy, the Netherlands, Slovakia, the Czech Republic, Germany, Finland, Romania, Greece and Estonia, some of which were already battling their own wildfires. It became the biggest activation of the UCPM mechanism this year.

European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen has pledged EU support to Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez to help with recovery of the affected areas, suggesting that resources such as the European Solidarity Fund could be used in the aftermath of the fire season.

France

France has been hit by its largest wildfire since 1949, which broke out at the beginning of the month in the municipality of Ribaute in the southern Occitania region and spread to 16,000 hectares. One woman died in the fire and 25 people were injured.

At times, more than 2,000 firefighters were deployed.

France has not activated the UCPM. However, the Slovak Fire and Rescue Corps (HaZZ) is deploying firefighters in the region from August 16 to 31.

Albania

Fires in EU candidate country Albania caused one death and burned hundreds of hectares of land and forests.

Albania received assistance through the UCPM, following fires in the south of the country on July 6. Two Canadair aircraft from the rescEU escort were mobilized to help control the situation.

From August 8 to 14, Albania activated the UCPM again to deal with a wave of fires that also affected neighbouring countries. The commission mobilized rescEU with aircraft from Croatia, Bulgaria, Italy, the Czech Republic and Slovakia.

Greece

An overall 323 European firefighters are stationed in Greece from July 1 to September 15, under the UCPM's pre-positioning programme. Firefighters from Austria, Bulgaria, France, Moldova, Romania and the Czech Republic are being deployed, with teams stationed in Attica, Thessaloniki and Patras.

According to available data, Greece has activated the mechanism twice so far. On July 26, Italy responded by deploying two firefighting aircraft. On August 12, the UCPM confirmed the deployment of two Swedish rescEU aircraft, previously stationed in Bulgaria.

Greece has responded to UCPM requests from other countries, deploying aircraft and firefighters to Spain, Portugal, Cyprus, Albania and North Macedonia in response to large-scale wildfires.

Bulgaria

Firefighters in Bulgaria have extinguished around 3,500 fires since the start of July, Bulgarian fire safety chief Alexander Dzhartov told the Trud newspaper in comments published on August 19. Some required the use of helicopters and planes provided through the UCPM.

Bulgarian firefighters were also sent abroad. On July 9, the Foreign Ministry said that a team with a fire engine was working to contain a blaze in Kriva Palanka, North Macedonia. Another team of firefighters was dispatched with two engines on July 2 to Vourvourou in northern Greece.

Awareness and training are key

In order to prepare citizens and firefighters alike for the new reality of more frequent wildfires, it is crucial to raise awareness among the population of how to stay safe and to equip firefighters with the necessary knowledge and tools.

The commission has said that the world broke its own temperature record last year. The average global temperature exceeded 1.5 degrees above pre-industrial levels, making 2024 the hottest year to date.

One dire consequence of the record-high temperatures is the increased risk of wildfires spreading.

A measure that Bulgaria employs is to have additional crews mobilized on high-risk days, especially weekends, when more people are outdoors.

Despite negligence being a leading cause, public engagement in fire prevention and suppression is growing. Forestry services, the armed forces, municipalities, farmers, businesses and volunteers are increasingly active in helping firefighters.

After the largest fire in Slovenian history in 2022 devastated the western part of the country on the border with Italy, it started to strengthen its firefighting capabilities, also with the help of European funds.

In March, during a visit by EU Budget Commissioner Piotr Serafin, the Slovenian Centre for Fighting Large Fires in the Natural Environment was officially opened in the town of Sezana. Firefighters are trained there according to a special programme adapted for protection and rescue, and it is equipped with modern equipment for responding to natural disasters.

Last but not least, technology and state-of-the-art warning systems are also vital to identify new fires before they are beyond control.

At the Pont du Gard in France, a Roman aqueduct located about thirty kilometers from Nîmes and visited by more than a million tourists each year, more than 120 small satellite-connected boxes were installed earlier this month, equipped with sensors measuring atmospheric pressure, temperature and humidity.

Developed by the German company Dryad, they are the first phase of a project designed to help firefighters better anticipate forest fires. Easily attached to tree trunks a few metres above the ground, they detect air quality and the presence of carbon monoxide or particulate matter in the air, within a radius of 200 meters.

After the testing phase, between 10,000 and 13,000 sensors will be installed and ready for use by early summer 2026, according to Eric Agrinier, head of communications for the Gard regional fire department.

The content of this article is based on reporting by AFP, AMNA, ANSA, ATA, BTA, dpa, EFE, Lusa, STA and TASR as part of the European Newsroom (enr) project.

urn:contentItem:6GPD-RCW3-RV88-M2D2-00000-00Completes Summer 2025 Exploration Program on the Genesis PGM Cu Ni Project, Alaska2025-09-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:58:42ZLexisNexisCompletes Summer 2025 Exploration Program on the Genesis PGM Cu Ni Project, Alaska

NEW AGE METALS INC ("NAM-V;NMTLF-0") - Completes Summer 2025 Exploration Program on the Genesis - PGM-Cu-Ni Project, Alaska

New Age Metals Inc. (NAM or the Company) provides an update on the 2025 field program at its 100%-owned Genesis PGM-Cu-Ni Project in southeast Alaska, approximately 65 km south of Glennallen and ~265 km east of Anchorage. The project is road-accessible and situated within 3 km of the all-season Richardson Highway and a high-capacity power line. From the Tonsina Lodge, which the exploration crew utilized during the program, it takes approximately one hour to access the site.

Highlights of the Genesis project are listed below: //st * The Genesis PGM-Cu-Ni Project is 100% owned by New Age Metals. * The Company is actively seeking an option/joint venture partner for our and its road-accessible Gensis PGE-Cu-Ni Project in Alaska. * The project is located within 3 km of the all-season paved Richardson highway and a high-capacity electric power line. * The Genesis property comprises 4,144 hectares of State of Alaska mining claims. * Two separate settings of magmatic reef-style mineralization occur: chromate-hosted Platinum Group Metals (PGM) returning up to 2.4 g/t palladium (Pd) and 2.4 g/t platinum (Pt); and nickel-copper (Ni-Cu)-bearing sulphide mineralization with values up to 0.96% Ni and 0.58% Cu. * Reef-style cumulate mineralization is open to the west, east, north and at depth. * Reef-style mineralization has been identified in outcrop for 2,000 metres along strike, with a 40-metre true thickness. * The 2025 Program focused on Sheep Hill area of the Project and approximately 134 rock samples were sent to the ALS lab to Reno, Nevada. * Known mineralization covers a distance of 9 km across the prospect. The target areas have never been drilled. A Technical Report is available.

Highlights of the Genesis project 2025 Exploration Program are listed below: //st * 2025 Sheep Hill program has been completed. Detailed mapping and prospecting focused on the western half of Sheep Hill were carried out at 1:1,000 scale; 134 rock samples were collected during July 1519, 2025. After QA/QC additions (blanks and standards), 163 samples were shipped to ALS in Reno. Assays are pending. * Access verified and improved logistics. The team mobilized from Anchorage to the base camp at Tonsina River Lodge and confirmed ~11 miles of ATV trail access to the Sheep Hill work area, including a safe Bernard Creek crossing. Travel time to the trailhead was refined to ~1 hour each way as routes were flagged. The program was completed within budget. * Genesis remains a 100% NAM-owned PGM-Cu-Ni project; two magmatic mineralization settings are present at surface;

* (i) chromite-hosted PGM up to 2.4 g/t Pd and 2.4 g/t Pt and (ii) Ni-Cu sulphide up to 0.96% Ni and 0.58% Cu . Reef-style mineralization is mapped in outcrop for ~2.0 km with ~40 m true thickness ; PGM mineralization spans ~9 km across the prospect; no drilling has yet tested these targets.

Figure 1: Map showing a portion of the ATV trail (red line), walking trail (green line) and the preliminary sample points (yellow dots) from the fieldwork portion of the project.

Figure 2. Location of Alaska Genesis Project

Figure 3: Image of Tonsina River Lodge which our technical crew utilized for the 2025 Field program. This facility is road accessible to the Alaska Genesis Project.

Figure 4. Map of the project area, lodging, proposed access route, and preliminary sampling grid.

Figure 5: Image showing the loaded ATV trailer and the trailing ATV with field crew members.

2025 Fieldwork Summary and Next Steps

The Company engaged Alaska Earth Sciences (AES) to execute a six-day, four-person program centered on Sheep Hill, following up on copper anomalies identified by Aurora Geosciences in 2021 and recommendations from the 2018 Technical Report. Work included detailed geological mapping at 1:1,000 to 1:2,000 scales, litho-geochemical grid planning (100 m 100 m where applicable), and targeted grab rock and sediment sampling.

Operational additions to the July 29 program outline are as follows: mobilization occurred July 14, with base camp at Tonsina River Lodge; ATV access (including Bernard Creek crossing) was physically confirmed and improved with flagged routes; consideration is being given to permitting a short ATV spur from the current parking area to the base of the mountain to streamline future sampling and support activities. A total of 163 samples (including QA/QC) were dispatched to ALSReno; results will be released once received and reviewed. After review of the results, NAM will have the consultants initiate an updated geological report which future recommendations.

Figure 6: Truck and trailer loaded with field gear and ATVs for the Gensis Project Summer Field Program.

Qualified Person

Robert M Retherford, CPG #10904, is a Qualified Person for the purposes of National Instrument 43-101 Standards of Disclosure for Mineral Projects and a consultant to NAM, has reviewed and approved the scientific and technical disclosure in this press release.

The Qualified Person has not completed sufficient work to verify the historical information on the project.

Issuance of Options

The Company also announces that it has granted 2,925,000 incentive stock options to directors, officers, employees, investor relations service provider, and consultants of the Company at an exercise price of $0.26 per share for a period of five (5) years from the date of grant in accordance with the Companys Stock Option Plan. The Stock Options granted will be subject to vesting restrictions, acceptance by the TSX Venture Exchange and are subject to regulatory hold periods in accordance with applicable Securities Laws.

About NAM

New Age Metals is a junior mineral exploration and development company focused on the discovery, exploration, and development of critical green metal projects in North America. The Company has three divisions: a Platinum Group Element division, a Lithium/Rare Element division, and a Antimony-Gold Division.

The PGE Division includes the 100% owned, multi-million-ounce, district-scale River Valley Project, one of North Americas largest undeveloped Platinum Group Element Projects, situated 100 km by road east of Sudbury, Ontario. In addition to River Valley, NAM owns 100% of the Genesis PGE-Cu-Ni Project in Alaska.

The Companys Lithium Division is one of the largest mineral claim holders in the Winnipeg River Pegmatite Field, where the Company is exploring hard rock lithium and various rare elements such as tantalum, rubidium, and cesium. NAM is developing its lithium division in conjunction with its Farm-in/Joint Venture agreement with Mineral Resources Ltd. (MinRes), one of the worlds largest lithium producers. A minimum budget to maintain the Projects has been approved by Mineral Resources Ltd for May 2025 to April 2026. The Companies agreed to the minimum budget due to current lithium pricing and forest fire dangers in the immediate area

In April 2024, a $1.5M NSERC Alliance grant was awarded to a collaboration led by the University of Manitoba (Drs. Fayek and Camacho), with academic partners from Lakehead University (Dr. Hollings) and industry partners including New Age Metals and Grid Metals. This research is focused on advancing Canadas critical metals sector, with New Age Metals portion targeting its Bird River lithium properties. Approximately $107,000 of work is planned on New Ages properties in 2025. The early work will include core sampling and field visits starting this summer. The project will likely extend beyond the original 3-year term, due to its delayed start.

New Age Metals Inc. is supporting a successful $180K Mitacs research grant, awarded in 2023, through its $90K contribution (already accounted for and paid under the Mineral Resources joint venture). This academic partnership with the University of New Brunswick and the University of British Columbia is focused on understanding the origin and controls of lithium pegmatite mineralization in the Cat LakeWinnipeg River field. Fieldwork for the MSc. thesis has been completed, while the post-doctoral phase is ongoing at UNB. This collaboration provides access to top-tier scientific expertise and equipment, significantly reducing analysis costs and adding long-term value to the project.

NAMs Antimony-Gold division is in Newfoundland and spans over 19,800 hectares consisting of 11 non-contiguous properties. Six of these properties are in St. Albans area, along Canstars Swanger and Little River mineralized trends. The remaining 5 properties are strategically located along the same geological trend as the past-producing Beaver Brook Antimony Mine and in proximity to New Found Golds Queensway South Gold Project. Management has recently completed Phase 1 of the Project, Phase 2 has been initiated, and further news will follow.

On August 6, 2025, New Age Metals announced an additional investment in a 4th critical metal. NAM currently owns approximately 12.79% and holds warrants that, if exercised with todays issued and outstanding shares of MQM, would bring NAM to a 19.05% interest in MetalQuest Mining inc.

MetalQuest Mining inc. is developing one of North Americas largest iron ore projects, where approximately $120 million has been spent on the project. For more information, please visit MetalQuestMining.com . High-purity iron ore became a critical metal Federally in Canada and in the Provinces of Quebec and Newfoundland and Labrador in 2024.

Management is currently aggressively seeking new mineral acquisition opportunities on an international scale. Our philosophy is to be a project generator with the objective of optioning our projects with major and junior mining companies through to production

The Company is actively seeking an option/joint venture partner for our and its road-accessible Genesis PGE-Cu-Ni Project in Alaska.

Opt-in List

If you have not done so already, we encourage you to sign up on our website (www.newagemetals.com) to receive our updated news.

On behalf of the Board of Directors

Harry Barr

Harry G. Barr

Chairman and CEO

urn:contentItem:6F14-DRR3-RS5R-1430-00000-00Researcher at Department of Computer Science Has Published New Study Findings on Machine Learning (Smart Wireless Sensor Networks with Virtual Sensors for Forest Fire Evolution Prediction Using Machine Learning)2025-01-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:58:42ZLexisNexisMACHINE LEARNINGResearcher at Department of Computer Science Has Published New Study Findings on Machine Learning (Smart Wireless Sensor Networks with Virtual Sensors for Forest Fire Evolution Prediction Using Machine Learning)


2025 JAN 30 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Telecommunications Daily -- Data detailed on artificial intelligence have been presented. According to news reporting from Socorro, New Mexico, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Forest fires are among the most devastating natural disasters, causing significant environmental and economic damage. Effective early prediction mechanisms are critical for minimizing these impacts."


Our news reporters obtained a quote from the research from Department of Computer Science: "In our previous work, we developed a smart and secure wireless sensor network (WSN) utilizing physical sensors to emulate forest fire dynamics and predict fire scenarios using machine learning. Building on this foundation, this study explores the integration of virtual sensors to enhance the prediction capabilities of the WSN. Virtual sensors were generated using polynomial regression models and incorporated into a supervector framework, effectively augmenting the data from physical sensors. The enhanced dataset was used to train a multi-layer perceptron neural network (MLP NN) to classify multiple fire scenarios, covering both early warning and advanced fire states. Our experimental results demonstrate that the addition of virtual sensors significantly improves the accuracy of fire scenario predictions, especially in complex situations like “Fire with Thundering” and “Fire with Thundering and Lightning”. The extended model's ability to predict early warning scenarios such as lightning and smoke is particularly promising for proactive fire management strategies. This paper highlights the potential of combining physical and virtual sensors in WSNs to achieve superior prediction accuracy and scalability of the field without any extra cost. Such findings pave the way for deploying scalable (cost-effective), intelligent monitoring systems capable of addressing the growing challenges of forest fire prevention and management. We obtained significant results in specific scenarios based on the number of virtual sensors added, while in some scenarios, the results were less promising compared to using only physical sensors."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "However, the integration of virtual sensors enables coverage of much larger areas, making it a highly promising approach despite these variations. Future work includes further optimization of the virtual sensor generation process and expanding the system's capability to handle large-scale forest environments. Moreover, utilizing virtual sensors will alleviate many challenges associated with the huge number of deployed physical sensors."
For more information on this research see: Smart Wireless Sensor Networks with Virtual Sensors for Forest Fire Evolution Prediction Using Machine Learning. Electronics, 2025,14(2). (Electronics - http://www.mdpi.com/journal/electronics). The publisher for Electronics is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/electronics14020223.
Our news journalists report that more information may be obtained by contacting Ahshanul Haque, Department of Computer Science, New Mexico Tech, Socorro, NM 87801, United States. Additional authors for this research include Hamdy Soliman.
ORCID is an identifier for authors and includes bibliographic information. The following is ORCID information for the author of this research: Ahshanul Haque (orcid.org/0000-0002-5571-7231).
Keywords for this news article include: Department of Computer Science, Socorro, New Mexico, United States, North and Central America, Cyborgs, Emerging Technologies, Machine Learning.
Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world. Copyright 2025, NewsRx LLC

urn:contentItem:6GGN-ND23-RS12-W3NJ-00000-00Biomass Sector, Lawmakers Urge EPA To Preserve RFS Electricity Credits2025-08-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:58:42ZLexisNexisBiomass Sector, Lawmakers Urge EPA To Preserve RFS Electricity Credits

August 8, 2025 Biomass producers, with support from lawmakers from both parties, are pressing EPA to retain the possibility of earning renewable fuel standard (RFS) credits for biomass electricity used in transportation, arguing that the Trump administration's aversion to electric vehicles (EVs) should not disadvantage other sectors.

EPA in its proposal setting RFS biofuel blending volumes for 2026 and 2027 categorically rules out any future issuance of the credits, known as electric renewable identification numbers (eRINs), regardless of which entities would benefit from the credits.

But one biomass industry source says this amounts to "throwing the baby out with the bathwater" because such credits could benefit the Trump administration's goal of using forest trimmings to reduce forest fire risks and to generate additional power.

Other potential beneficiaries of eRINs could include those producing power from agricultural biogas or landfills -- without providing any subsidy to EV manufacturers or charging station operators, the source says.

In Aug. 6 comments on EPA's proposal, the American Biomass Energy Association, American Loggers Council, California Biomass Energy Alliance (CBEA) and Michigan Biomass urge EPA not to foreclose the possibility of eRINs. They also cite an apparent contradiction with the agency's acceptance of renewable natural gas (RNG) as a credit-earning "fuel" under the RFS.

Use of such RNG accounts for the majority of the "cellulosic" biofuel category under the program, even though it is a gas and not a liquid fuel.

"EPA can rely on the fact that it is a longstanding matter of federal law to treat electricity as a fuel," the groups say, citing the Energy Policy Act of 1992.

"Preserving the electricity pathway while eliminating subsidies for the EV sector are not mutually exclusive. The electricity pathway was never intended to promote EVs. No other transportation fuel in the RFS program treats the user of the fuel, i.e., the vehicle end-user, as the 'producer' of RINs. That is contrary to the plain language of the statute," the groups say.

While Obama-era proposals explored granting eRINs to EV makers or charging station operators, these ideas were not "consistent with existing law," the groups say.

The trade associations note that Congress has frequently directed EPA to establish "pathways" for eRIN generation. Although EPA has established such pathways for certain feedstocks -- such as RNG -- it has not done so for all. And no administration has yet established a workable framework for granting eRINs, and thus none have been issued.

"Congress has similarly endorsed EPA's interpretation of "renewable fuels" and further encouraged EPA to utilize the renewable electricity pathway. On seven separate occasions since 2019, Congressional appropriators have expressed frustration with the backlog of applications seeking to generate RINs from the electricity pathway and have demanded the agency act on pending applications," the biomass groups say.

"In 2020, Congress even allocated $500,000 for the purpose of processing applications to make use of the renewable electricity pathway. In sum, Congress has repeatedly endorsed EPA's power to implement the electricity program and pushed the agency to do so expeditiously," the groups add.

Senate FY26 Report

The Senate Appropriations Committee on July 24 also voiced support for the eRIN program.

In report language attached to the panel's fiscal year 2026 spending bill for EPA, which lawmakers approved on a 26-2 vote, the committee noted that EPA "still has not implemented the electricity program under the Renewable Fuel Standard (RFS), despite past direction from this committee."

The report directs EPA to "finalize the eRINs program within 90 days of enactment of this act and to process all electric pathway feedstock petitions prior to issuing the final 2026 Renewable Volume Obligation rule."

The Appropriations Committee said it "expects that the eRIN program will be implemented with all eligible feedstocks, particularly those that support agriculture activity, minimize wildfire risk, and reduce methane emissions."

Committee Chair Susan Collins (R-ME) is a key champion of the biomass sector and its efforts to win RFS credit, along with Sen. Jeanne Shaheen (D-NH), the biofuels industry source says, adding that there is substantial bipartisan support in the House for this effort.

The biomass groups in their comments say: "Because prior EPAs have decided to make the [cellulosic RIN] market almost entirely the exclusive domain of RNG, this has incentivized the conversion of landfill-gas-to-electricity facilities from providing baseload power to RNG production, all the while failing to support baseload biomass electricity, and all because of EPA policies that are contrary to President Trump's energy policies."

"Biomass power's exclusion from the [cellulosic] program has directly and negatively impacted baseload power capacity and good-paying rural jobs. In the last decade, 25 biomass facilities have closed, resulting in an estimated loss of 20% of the total capacity of the industry and contributing to a staggering loss of logging jobs across the country," the groups say.

"This trend is directly contrary to the President's executive orders, including EO 14213 to further domestic energy dominance, EO 14216 to increase baseload power, and EO 14260 to promote affordable and reliable energy."

Two additional orders, EO 14225 and EO 14308, "are directly relevant to EPA's decision to exclude electricity from the RFS. Specifically, EO 14225 encourages federal agencies to find 'tools to facilitate the increase' in bioenergy production. Inclusion of biomass derived electricity in the . . . program is exactly such a tool. Additionally, because many biomass power facilities utilize forest residues that would otherwise contribute to wildfires, EO 14308 is applicable."

The associations ask EPA to: maintain renewable electricity in the RFS program; process all pending biomass power pathways; finalize a simplified electricity pathway program that creates greater market competition while not burdening consumers or refiners; and remove the ability for the program to serve as an incentive for the EV industry by designating power generators as the sole "producer."

However, there is so far no indication that the Trump EPA will move from its categorical rejection of electricity as a qualifying "fuel" under the RFS. And other major sectors affected by the program, including ethanol and biodiesel producers and refiners, are pursuing policies that benefit liquid fuels over other types. -- Stuart Parker (sparker@iwpnews.com)

urn:contentItem:6GJS-G0W3-RS1P-J1J8-00000-00Fires in Spain: the weather is helping firefighting efforts and opens the door to optimism2025-08-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:58:42ZLexisNexisFires in Spain: the weather is helping firefighting efforts and opens the door to optimism


It seems that the worst is over in the episode of fires that Spain is experiencing during this month of August. About 350,000 hectares have burned during 2025, and the vast majority of them have done so in the Great Forest Fires of this month. Specifically, 79% of this surface area was concentrated in the communities of Galicia and Castilla y León, according to information from the European Forest Fire Information System.


At present, around twenty fires are still active in the country. Specifically, there are 12 active fires in Castilla y León, one in Extremadura and eight in Galicia, however, the good weather conditions have allowed to work more easily in the extinguishing tasks. From Sunday a DANA could leave a change in the weather, with rainfall and a new drop in temperatures in the north of the peninsula that will help in the fight against forest fires.
CASTILLA AND LEÓNCecopi remains optimistic despite the fact that 12 fires are still active.
The Cecopi of León has shown on Friday its optimism about the situation of the province to the fires due to the weather, since the increase in humidity and the support of troops arrived from other autonomous communities allows to maintain a steady pace in extinction.
In spite of everything, 1,524 inhabitants of 27 localities continue evacuated, being the last five neighbors of Anllarinos. The fire extinguishing services in the province are now focusing their work on the fires affecting Llamas de Cabrera, Fasgar, Barniedo, Colinas and Anllares, with special attention to the penultimate one due to the risk of its advance towards the Tremor area.
There is also a risk of reproduction in the Llamas de la Cabrera fire and the Gestoso fire, the latter already without flames. The fires in Yeres and Molezuelas de la Carballeda, where active surveillance of the perimeter continues, are evolving favorably. According to the latest updated data from the Directorate General of Traffic (DGT), eight roads are cut by the fire, all of them secondary: four in León, two in Zamora, one in Palencia and one more in Cáceres.
GALICIAThe Laoruco fire is still active, but the rest of the fires have been stabilized.
In Galicia, eight fires are still active on Friday, five of them in Ourense and another three in Pontevedra and Lugo. The fire in Carballedo (Lugo) maintains active situation 2 due to its proximity to the town of Oleiros and has forced the preventive evacuation of 53 children and 11 monitors from the Albergue dos Peares. The Laoruco fire, the largest in the history of Galicia, is still of concern, but the Muiños fire has been controlled and the fires in Carballeda de Avia, Vilardevós, Maceda, Fumaces and Trepa, Moialde, Ríos-Trasestrada and Montederramo-Paredes have been stabilized.
In Ourense no new confinements or evacuations were recorded during the night, and all main roads remain operational.
EXTREMADURAJarilla fire stabilized, the largest in the history of the community
The Jarilla fire, the only one in Extremadura and the largest in the history of the autonomous community, has been stabilized. This has been communicated this Friday by the Minister of Presidency of Extremadura, Abel Bautista, from the emergency operation of the fire.
At the moment there are some hot spots in the northwest of the fire, where six air assets and more than 200 other troops will be concentrated today on the perimeter, after a night "somewhat complicated" but in which the fire has been perimetered.
On the other hand, from 17.00 the neighbors of the houses of the periurban area of Hervás will return to their homes and, at this moment, also return to their homes those of the isolated houses of Jerte, Tornavacas, Cabezuela del Valle and Navaconcejo. At the moment, more than 17,300 hectares have burned in Jarilla, in a perimeter of 170 kilometers.
ASTURIASNo active outbreaks in the Picos de Europa area.
Three fires are still active in the southwest of Asturias, one in the region of Degaña, and two others in Somiedo and Cangas del Narcea, while there is no active fire in the area of Picos de Europa as those of Ponga, Cabrales and Peñamellera Baja are stabilized or controlled.
Compared to the twenty fires that in the past days were registered simultaneously in Asturias, today have been reduced to eight: the three active fires in the southwest, as many others that are stabilized and two more controlled.
Arson41 people arrested and 127 investigated for their possible relationship with the origin of the fires.
During the fires that have burned throughout 2025, the Castilian-Leonese community has taken the worst part with some 151,135 hectares burned, being 96,870 of them in León -the most affected province in the whole country-, and 30,644 in Zamora. Galicia is next with a total of 105,547 hectares burned, especially Ourense with 96,779 ha.
Extremadura is the third most affected with 47,075 hectares lost, with 34,778 ha burned in the province of Cáceres. The rest of the autonomous communities show smaller figures compared to the previous ones, such as Catalonia (8,115 ha), Community of Madrid (3,850 ha), Andalusia (2,660 ha), Asturias (2,298 ha), Castilla-La Mancha (2,208 ha), Cantabria (656) and the Valencian Community (469 ha).
According to the Undersecretary of the Ministry of the Interior, Susana Crisóstomo, at the moment there are 41 people arrested and 127 under investigation for their possible relationship with the origin of the fires. All the forestry brigades of the Ministry of Ecological Transition are still operating in seven of the fires, as well as 45 aerial means that carry out unloading missions on a daily basis. The UME is acting in nine fires, where it is concentrating the deployment of its 1,400 troops, who are supported by another 1,000 military personnel from other units of the three armies.
International assistance to extinguish the fires
In addition, means from eight European countries are operating in the different fires under the coordination of the General Directorate of Civil Protection and Emergencies. In particular, two Italian tanker planes, whose period of action has been extended until August 24, two helicopters from the Netherlands, a helicopter from the Czech Republic and a helicopter from Slovakia are working on the fires.
Likewise, 26 firefighters from Finland continue working in the extinguishing tasks, who have been integrated in an Estonian contingent that was already in Spain (Orense) in a mission of exchange of good practices organized by the EU during the summer campaign.
Also two teams of firefighters from France (66 troops and 23 vehicles) are working in León, a team of firefighters from Germany (60 troops and 24 vehicles) in Extremadura, a team from Andorra in Asturias, 51 forest firefighters from Romania have joined this Friday the firefighting work in Galicia and a team of 20 forest firefighters from Greece has had to delay their arrival in Asturias, where they will immediately join the firefighting work.

urn:contentItem:6FCB-GXM3-RWD0-705Y-00000-00DEEP REMINDS RESIDENTS TO EXERCISE CAUTION DURING SPRING BRUSH FIRE SEASON2025-03-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:58:42ZLexisNexisDEEP REMINDS RESIDENTS TO EXERCISE CAUTION DURING SPRING BRUSH FIRE SEASONStates News ServiceHARTFORD, CT

The following information was released by the Connecticut Department of Energy and Environmental Protection (DEEP):

Season Typically Runs From Mid-March to Mid-May; Important For Residents to Be Aware and Take Proper Precautions

(HARTFORD)The Connecticut Department of Energy and Environmental Protection is reminding residents that the typical spring brush fire season in Connecticut runs from mid-March through mid-May, and there are important precautions residents should take to minimize the likelihood of a fire.

After the snow melts in the northeastern part of the U.S., we enter into a traditional spring fire season. This is a time of year when deciduous (non-evergreen) trees are bare, allowing the warm spring sun to heat up forest fuels. Forest fuels consist of anything that burns, such as grass, leaves, twigs, branches, and decaying material in the soil. As the days grow longer and the sun gets hotter, the fuels that are most exposed quickly dry out. Grasses, twigs, and small branches are called "1-hour fuels," meaning they can dry out and become ready to burn within an hour. Larger fuels take longer to dry out. Typically, fires that start at this time of year burn just these 1-hour fuels and can spread very fast, particularly when its windy.

Brush fires are a serious hazard and can threaten lives and infrastructure. In 2024, Connecticut had a total of 605 wildfires, with 510 acres impacted. Tragically, a firefighter died while responding to a brush fire in fall 2024, and eight other firefighters were injured in 2024 while responding to brush fires. One residential building and seven other structures were lost to wildfire. Overall in 2024, 170 structures and residences were at risk for damage from wildfires.

The majority of wildfires in Connecticut are caused by human actions such as improper burning of debris or poor management of campfires, arson, careless discarding of wood ashes, and placing motorized equipment on top of or adjacent to fire fuels.

As we saw from our historic brush fire season last fall, brush fires are a serious hazard, particularly in a densely populated state like Connecticut, DEEP Commissioner Katie Dykes said. With increasingly extreme weather conditions, its all the more important for residents to be vigilant and careful when burning anything outdoors. Its important to remember that local open burning permits are automatically suspended on days when the fire danger level is high, very high, or extreme. Please be sure to properly dispose of wood ashes, make sure all campfires are completely extinguished and wet and cool to the touch before leaving the area, and take proper care when extinguishing and disposing of smoking materials such as cigarette butts.

As we have seen across the country, and recently here in CT, wildland fires can quickly threaten homes and other structures, State Fire Marshal Lauri Volkert said. Even a small camp fire can turn deadly in a matter of minutes. Make sure an alert adult constantly attends to every outdoor fire. Teach children how to be safe around fire by keeping a 3-foot kid-free zone around any campfire, storing matches and lighters securely out of kids reach and modeling responsible behavior around fire.

DEEP's Forest Fire Control Office urges all who enjoy Connecticut's parks, forests and open spaces to use fires with caution and heed the following recommendations, especially during forest fire season:

Obey local laws regarding open fires, including campfires.

Keep all flammable objects away from fire. Scrape away leaves, twigs, and grass within a 10-foot diameter circle from fire.

Have firefighting tools nearby and handy.

Never leave a fire unattended.

Carefully dispose of hot coal/ashes.

Drown all fires.

Carefully extinguish smoking materials.

For Connecticut homeowners and residents, the following best practices are suggested to protect your family members and home:

Make a fire-safe zone around your house. Clean flammable vegetation and debris from at least 30 feet around the house and any outbuildings.

Prune away the lower limbs of evergreens that are within the fire-safe zone. Evergreens catch fire easily during dry periods and burn quickly.

Remove any limbs which overhang the roof or chimney.

Regularly remove leaves and needles from gutters.

Do not store firewood in the fire-safe zone.

Use fire-resistant roofing materials.

Make sure firefighters can find and access your home. Mark your house and roads clearly and prune away limbs and trees along your driveway which do not allow fire truck access.

Have an escape plan-- and practice it.

Follow state and local open burning laws.

Stay with outside fires until they are completely safe and extinguished.

Dispose of wood ashes in a metal bucket, soak them with water before dumping them.

Local open burning permits are automatically suspended on days when the fire danger level is high.

Municipal issued open burn permits are automatically suspended if the Daily Forest Fire Danger Index is rated High, Very High, or Extreme)

Open Burning

Daily Forest Fire Danger Report

To sign up for DEEPs daily Forest Fire Danger Report, go here: Forest Fire Weather Information and Danger Explanations

If you spot a forest fire, remain calm, go to the nearest telephone and dial 911 to report the fire as quickly as possible to your local fire department. Tell the emergency dispatcher when and where you saw the fire. If you see anything suspicious at or near the scene of the fire, take note and relay that to the dispatcher as well. Stay on the telephone until the dispatcher tells you to hang up.

Helpful Resources

Forest Fire Prevention Tips

For more information on forest fire prevention, visit the Smokey Bear website.

urn:contentItem:6GM9-JCT3-RRYD-K4J6-00000-00ENVIRONMENT - How forests decimated by wildfires still have the power to heal2025-08-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:58:42ZLexisNexisENVIRONMENT - How forests decimated by wildfires still have the power to healRFI

Wildfires that ripped through Europe this summer, forcing thousands to flee and leaving vast areas of forest in ashes, were the worst the continent has seen in decades. Scientists say climate extremes are driving the destruction. Yet forests have an incredible capacity to recover – sometimes naturally, and sometimes with human help.

In recent years, forest fires have destroyed millions of hectares of vegetation in North America, southern Europe, Australia, and especially in Africa.

Once the flames die down, forests can regenerate naturally or with intervention. Depending on the trees and the location, recovery can take anywhere from three to 60 years.

Forests can recover if the right conditions are in place – whether through natural regrowth, human intervention or replanting. These techniques differ slightly depending on geographic zones and climate patterns.

Many experts say natural regeneration is usually the most effective.

Éric Rigolot, a research engineer at France's National Institute for Agricultural, Food, and Environmental Research (Inrae), specialises in Mediterranean forest ecology.

"For the most part, the forest will manage to regenerate on its own," he told RFI.

"Mediterranean forests, for example, are adapted to a certain fire regime. They have developed effective methods for post-fire regeneration."

Fire-resistant bark

Some species, like the cork oak, are especially resilient. "Three weeks after a fire, there can already be young shoots appearing on the trunk," Rigolot said.

Other trees survive thanks to their bark.

"Those with more fire-resistant bark won't necessarily die: they'll sprout again with buds that will reform in the following years," Jonathan Lenoir, an ecologist and research fellow at CNRS, said.

Forests can turn green again quickly after rainfall.

"If there is good natural regeneration capacity, we will see a return of trees in the following years," said Rémi Savazzi, head of the National Forestry Office's (ONF) fire division.

Underground roots can also survive, allowing vegetation to "grow back from the stump".

Protecting the soil is the first priority after a forest fire.

"The forest has a role in protecting the soil and against other natural hazards," Savazzi explained.

Measures are taken to repair walking trails and to identify damaged trees or trees about to fall.

Trees affected by fire can be repurposed into anti-erosion barriers that "slow down runoff and maintain the soil", Savazzi added.

Climate change made LA wildfires 'more likely' according to international study

Human intervention

For some scientists, human involvement helps forests recover faster.

"We need to ensure that invasive species like weeds don't proliferate. This will help native species regrow more easily," said Patrick Norman, a researcher at Griffith University in Australia.

In Canada, some trees sow seeds when they burn, thus participating in natural forest regeneration. This is the case for certain conifers in the country's boreal forests.

Victor Danneyrolles, a researcher at the University of Quebec and a specialist in fire ecology told RFI that this is a very effective mechanism in allowing trees to regenerate after a fire.

"There are seed systems enclosed in serotinous cones. There is a resin in the cone, which will melt when the fire passes, opening the cone, and allowing all the seeds to be released," he said.

While natural regeneration is prioritised where possible, sometimes a helping hand is needed – particularly when it comes to planting.

For many years in France, the planting of new trees and new seeds by humans was an integral part of the forest healing process but it hasn't always been effective.

"We have examples of our colleagues 30 or 40 years ago who replanted as soon as there was a gap. We realise that some plantations have unfortunately failed," ONF's Savazzi said.

In the Mediterranean region, the last planting programs took place in the 1980s, according to Inrae, but this has become too expensive to maintain.

Danneyrolles indicates that in Quebec, the price of replanting corresponds to $8,000 per hectare, or nearly €5,000.

"You have to produce the seeds, then plants in nurseries, build forest roads to access the areas to be reforested, labour costs," he said.

France's worst wildfires in 30 years force a rethink on managing forests

Choice of tree species

Furthermore, replanting, while still used in many countries, can be risky if done poorly or if the species planted are not well chosen.

"We may be tempted to plant species that are more resistant to fire, and which sometimes come from far away. These species can be invasive and cause other problems," said Jonathan Lenoir of the CNRS.

Lenoir instead advocates replanting a "mixture of species" to "avoid the spread of fire, which can be more prevalent when tree species are homogenous.

Australian researcher Patrick Norman insists on planting something that's native to the area, "something that should originally grow there," he says.

"Planting an exotic species like a eucalyptus (a species widely found in Australian forests), which burns very well, would significantly exacerbate the problem" in unsuitable forests.

In many countries, the regeneration of forests is a combination of techniques.

In Morocco, the National Agency for Water and Forests (ANEF) sets aside closed areas to allow vegetation to regrow without disturbance, alongside reforestation with drought-resistant native species.

After fires in the Landes de Gascogne region of France in 2022, "most of the maritime pine forests were replanted," Rigolot said. Planting is also taking place along the Atlantic coast of Spain and Portugal.

New tools like drones are being tested in Canada, Spain and Mexico. In Michoacan, some drone models can carry nearly 20 kilos of seeds, Danneyrolles said.

Indigenous input

Some countries, such as Australia, draw on the knowledge of indigenous communities to develop more sustainable regeneration strategies for fire-affected areas.

"They are an incredible source of knowledge; they have maintained the environment and lived with fires for nearly 50,000 years. Who knows the affected regions better than the First Nations' people?" Australian researcher Patrick Norman said.

Victor Danneyrolles agrees with this when it comes to Canada.

"They are generally the most exposed to the risk of fires, because some live in somewhat isolated areas. We work with them as much as possible to understand their needs and realities."

Traditional techniques such as controlled burns are now widely used in Australia and Canada. Indigenous groups are also exploring the use of drones, which avoid building roads or bringing in heavy machinery.

Generations to grow

Even when regeneration is quick, full recovery can take decades.

"It will take 20 to 30 years for small trees to become adult trees and be able to reseed," Savazzi said.

Norman recalled Australia's "Black Summer" of 2019-2020, when "trees that were thought to be dead sprouted two or three years later." Still, he noted that some ecosystems can take "up to 20 years to return to the state they were in before the fires."

When it comes to ancient forests, an even longer period is required, according to Rigolot from Inrae – who points to the fires earlier this month in the Aude department of France.

"To rebuild a mature forest, like the one that burned in the Corbières, it takes many years, almost a human generation, or almost 60 to 70 years. The forest is an ecosystem with a very long life cycle," he said.

The process of reforestation and restoration that can take even longer if disrupted by repeated or overly massive fires.

Biggest French wildfire since 1949 a 'catastrophe on an unprecedented scale'

Resilience as key

In Quebec, after the mega-fires that ravaged several million hectares in 2023, some forests, for example, have been unable to regenerate on their own.

"It is estimated that more than 300,000 hectares will not be able to reforest themselves. We are capable of reforesting ourselves, but only up to 50,000 hectares per year," Danneyrolles said.

For Jonathan Lenoir, climate change will involve a different adaptation of forest ecosystems, to put the emphasis on resilience. This may lead to the disappearance of certain species better adapted to a more humid climate.

"We risk having species better adapted to hot and dry climates naturally, or, through assisted migration, humans will seek to favour species adapted to these new conditions," he said.

With already 8 to 10 million hectares of natural forests disappearing each year, the NGO World Wildlife Fund says helping forests adapt will be essential. Forests provide livelihoods for more than 300 million people and are home to 80 percent of terrestrial biodiversity.

This report was adapted from the original version in French by RFI's Léo Roussel.

SECTION 2 CORPORATE PROFILE AND INDEPENDENT RATINGS

2.1 Activities

Weyerhaeuser Company, headquartered in Seattle, Washington, is one of the largest private owners of timberlands in the world, with a history dating back to 1900. Its core business activities center on sustainable forest management, timber harvesting, and the production of wood products. The company''s largest sources of revenue come from its Timberlands segment, which includes the sale of logs and timber, and its Wood Products segment, which manufactures and distributes lumber, engineered wood, and other building materials primarily for residential and commercial construction. Additionally, Weyerhaeuser operates a Real Estate, Energy, and Natural Resources segment, focusing on land sales and renewable energy opportunities. Among its business lines, the Wood Products segment has shown notable growth, driven by strong demand in the housing and construction markets. With a commitment to environmental stewardship, Weyerhaeuser continues to balance profitability with sustainable practices across its extensive land holdings. It is the NYSE's 5th largest Building materials & fixtures company by market capitalisation.

In FY 2024, the top earner of Revenue was WOOD PRODUCTS [68%] followed by TIMBERLANDS [26.9%] at Rank 2 and REAL ESTATE & ENR [5.1%] at Rank 3. In FY 2024, revenue growth was highest in REAL ESTATE & ENR [7.7%] .

Press Release article 1 of 17, 286 words

October 11: Weyerhaeuser Commits $1 Million to Buckhannon's Future

Weyerhaeuser Company is set to make a significant impact in the rural town of Buckhannon, West Virginia, with a $1 million investment through its Thrive program. This announcement comes as part of the company's ongoing commitment to support the communities that play a vital role in its operations. The investment will be rolled out over several years, aiming to uplift the local economy and enhance the quality of life for residents in this town of approximately 5,000 people.

The investment was announced on 2025-10-11 and aims to address various needs within Buckhannon, including infrastructure improvements, workforce development, attainable housing, and recreational opportunities. Nancy Thompson, senior director of advocacy and philanthropy at Weyerhaeuser, emphasized the company's recognition of the interdependent relationship it shares with rural communities. "We at Weyerhaeuser realize that we are really important to these rural economies, and the reverse is absolutely true. The rural communities are important to Weyerhaeuser's success," she stated.

Weyerhaeuser's Thrive program, launched in 2023, is designed to provide targeted support to rural communities facing significant challenges. With Buckhannon being the third community selected for this initiative, the program reflects Weyerhaeuser's strategic focus on long-term investments that foster growth and sustainability. Thompson noted, "It's really all about strengthening the communities that are important to Weyerhaeuser and we know that our jobs are important to those communities."

The specific allocation of the $1 million funds will be determined through collaborative discussions with Buckhannon residents and community leaders in the coming months. This approach ensures that the investment addresses the most pressing needs and empowers the local population to play an active role in shaping their community's future.

Press Release article 2 of 17, 342 words

October 07: Weyerhaeuser's $1 Million Commitment to Buckhannon Signals Long-Term Strategy

BUCKHANNON, W.Va. (WV News) - Weyerhaeuser Company has announced a commitment to invest $1 million in Buckhannon through the company's THRIVE program. This investment will be made over the next several years, with input from local elected officials, business leaders, nonprofits, employees, and other community partners. The announcement comes as part of Weyerhaeuser's ongoing efforts to enhance rural communities, marking Buckhannon as the third selected community since the program's launch in 2023.

"Rural operating communities like Buckhannon are so important to the success of our business and to the greater health of the forest products industry," Stockfish stated. "We want to make sure these communities remain great places to live, work, and do business for years to come. Weyerhaeuser has maintained an engineered wood products plant in Buckhannon for over 25 years, consistently ranking among its top-performing sites for safety and manufacturing reliability. In addition, the company operates an oriented strand board mill in nearby Sutton and sustainably manages over 250,000 acres of timberlands across West Virginia. The investment in Buckhannon is seen as a significant step towards fostering a collaborative relationship between the company and the local community.

Robbie Skinner, mayor of Buckhannon, expressed enthusiasm about the investment, noting, "We are excited and grateful to be selected as Weyerhaeuser's next THRIVE community. This investment is a clear signal of Weyerhaeuser's commitment to Buckhannon, and we look forward to partnering with company leaders and the people of this great community to build a stronger and better future together." The THRIVE program aims to address local challenges through long-term collaboration, investment, and advocacy.

October 07: Weyerhaeuser Company Supports Row River with Land Donation for Fire Substation

COTTAGE GROVE, Ore. - Weyerhaeuser Company Tuesday announced it has donated 38 acres of land in Disston, Ore. to Row River Fire Response (RRFR). The donated land, which connects the Row River and Lower Brice Creek areas, will serve as the site for a new RRFR emergency substation facility for the Row River Rural Fire Protection, aimed at improving wildfire response times. This announcement comes on the 7th of October, 2025, reflecting Weyerhaeuser's ongoing commitment to community and environmental responsibility.

RRFR is an Oregon 501(c)(3) nonprofit that provides support for fire and emergency services in the Row River Valley, a rural area outside Cottage Grove that experiences high wildfire risk each summer. Historically, this region has not had rapid access to city fire department services. Weyerhaeuser noted in a media release that rural fire protection districts often operate with limited resources and are frequently the first responders to wildfires in remote or hard-to-reach areas across Oregon.

Lyndcy Patrick, land use manager at Weyerhaeuser, stated, "Thriving, resilient communities are vital to the well-being of our employees, our neighbors, and the places where we live and work in Oregon. By supporting organizations like RRFR, Weyerhaeuser can make a real difference in wildfire response and help ensure these first responders can keep our communities and forests healthy." This donation follows a $25,000 grant Weyerhaeuser awarded to RRFR in 2023 through its Giving Fund to support infrastructure costs for the new fire facility.

The new Disston Substation will be a satellite fire station equipped with a fire truck and water tender. This facility is expected to significantly enhance emergency response times in Dorena, Culp Creek, and surrounding areas. Kathleen Istudor, Executive Director at RRFR, expressed gratitude, stating, "We can't thank Weyerhaeuser enough for this generous donation and their support for the strength and resilience of rural communities.

September 02: Weyerhaeuser Concludes Sale of Princeton Lumber Mill to Gorman Group

Weyerhaeuser Company has completed the sale of its lumber mill in Princeton, British Columbia, to the Gorman Group. This transaction, initially announced in May, includes the transfer of Weyerhaeuser's associated timber licenses in British Columbia, which are expected to be finalized in the coming months, subject to regulatory review and customary closing conditions.

As part of the sale, Weyerhaeuser received approximately $60 million USD upfront, with additional proceeds tied to the transfer of the timber licenses. The company has recognized a gain from the sale but anticipates a tax liability of about $11 million USD as a result of the transaction. This sale reflects Weyerhaeuser's ongoing strategy to optimize its operations and focus on its core business areas.

Established in 1900, Weyerhaeuser is among the largest private owners of timberlands worldwide, managing approximately 10.4 million acres in the U.S. and additional public timberlands in Canada. The company is recognized for its commitment to sustainability, operating all its timberlands in compliance with internationally recognized forestry standards. In 2024, Weyerhaeuser reported net sales of $7.1 billion and employed around 9,400 people globally.

The Gorman Group, a family-owned business founded in 1951, operates multiple divisions in Southern British Columbia and northern Washington state, employing about 900 individuals. The company is well-regarded for its high-value lumber products, particularly in the home finishing and renovation markets. The acquisition of Weyerhaeuser's mill aligns with Gorman Group's long-term strategy of enhancing its operational capabilities and market presence.

Weyerhaeuser's decision to divest its Princeton mill is part of a broader trend in the timber industry, where companies are reassessing their portfolios to focus on areas with higher growth potential.

May 28: Weyerhaeuser, Firefighter Behavioral Health Alliance Partner for Fourth Year to Provide Mental Health Resources for Wildland Firefighters

Fighting Fires Together campaign raises awareness and helps address mental health challenges of wildland firefighting

SEATTLE, May 28, 2025- Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) and Firefighter Behavioral Health Alliance (FBHA) today announced an extension of their Fighting Fires Together campaign, a partnership that provides specialized mental health support for wildland firefighters and their families across the Pacific Northwest.

Fighting Fires Together, now in its fourth year, addresses the often-overlooked mental health impacts of wildland firefighting in isolated, hazardous and highly stressful conditions. Through a free online resource hub, first responders can find specially designed content, including videos about Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), depression, anxiety and suicide prevention, along with mental health tips, educational articles and contacts for occupationally aware support groups and counselors in Oregon, Washington and British Columbia.

Weyerhaeuser's support for wildland firefighting efforts in the Pacific Northwest began in the aftermath of the Yacolt Burn in 1902, when the company began advocating for Washington's first forest fire legislation and the funding of community fire prevention education and patrols. Today, as Weyerhaeuser celebrates its 125th anniversary, the company continues to play an active role in fire prevention and response through its forest management operations. Weyerhaeuser employees and contractors receive annual fire readiness training, build fire breaks and containment lines, conduct aerial surveys and deploy tanker trucks, helicopters and quick-response crews to wildland fires.

"After launching the Fighting Fires Together campaign with FBHA four years ago, we're proud to continue this effort to support wildland firefighters and their mental health as they work in challenging conditions to protect our communities," says Bill Frings, vice president of Western Timberlands for Weyerhaeuser.
